choices.text: Immediate referral for colposcopy and biopsy

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents for her routine gynecological examination. She is asymptomatic. A Pap smear reveals high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). What is the next appropriate step in her management?
questions.solution:
HSIL on Pap smear indicates a significant risk of cervical cancer or its precursors. Immediate referral for colposcopy and biopsy is necessary to further evaluate the lesion and determine the extent of dysplasia or malignancy.

OPTION A: HSIL is a significant abnormality that indicates a high risk of cervical precancer or cancer. Repeating the Pap smear without further evaluation is not appropriate as it delays necessary diagnostic intervention.

OPTION B: OPTION C: Observation and follow-up are not recommended for HSIL due to the increased risk of progression to cervical cancer. Immediate diagnostic evaluation is necessary.

OPTION D: HPV vaccination can prevent future infections with HPV types that cause cervical cancer, it does not address existing HSIL. The immediate priority is to evaluate and manage the current lesion.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (HSIL) refer to moderate to severe changes in the cells of the cervix.
  • The risk that HSIL abnormalities signify precancerous changes is as high as 53 percent, and the risk of cervical cancer is as high as 7 percent.
  • For most people with HSIL on a Pap test, follow-up involves a colposcopy.
  • In some cases, the clinician will advise immediate (expedited) treatment at the same visit as the colposcopy with a "loop electrosurgical excision procedure" (also called a LEEP or large loop excision of the transformation zone [LLETZ]).

Reference: ASCCP Guidelines on Pap Smear Cytology

questions.text: A 37 year-old woman has been diagnosed with stage IB1 cervical cancer. She desires to preserve fertility. Which of the following is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Radical trachelectomy involves the removal of the cervix and the upper part of the vagina while preserving the uterus, allowing the possibility of future pregnancies. It is an appropriate option for women with stage IB1 cervical cancer who wish to preserve fertility.

Explanation

OPTION B: Radical hysterectomy involves the removal of the uterus and cervix, which eliminates the possibility of future pregnancies. While it is an effective treatment for stage IB1 cervical cancer, it is not suitable for a patient who desires to preserve fertility.

OPTION C: Chemoradiation is a non-surgical treatment option that is highly effective for cervical cancer but leads to infertility due to radiation effects on the ovaries and uterus. It is not appropriate for patients who want to preserve fertility.

OPTION D: LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure) is typically used for the treatment of precancerous lesions or very early-stage cervical cancer (like CIN II or III), not for stage IB1 cervical cancer. It would be inadequate for treating Stage IB1, which requires more extensive surgical intervention.

FIGO Staging of Cervical Cancer:-

KEY TAKEAWAY: Radical trachelectomy is an effective and fertility-preserving option for women with early-stage cervical cancer. It balances cancer treatment with the desire to maintain the possibility of future pregnancies.

Best suited for women with early-stage cervical cancer, particularly stage IA2 and IB1 (tumor size ≤2 cm) without lymph node involvement or distant metastasis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with deranged RFTs and a pelvic mass. Examination reveals a large, fixed mass involving the cervix and extending to the lateral pelvic wall. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her cervical cancer?
questions.solution:
Stage IIIB cervical cancer involves extension to the pelvic wall and/or causes hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney, which is consistent with the patient's presentation of a large, fixed mass and deranged RFTs.

OPTION A: Stage IIB: This stage indicates the spread of the tumor beyond the cervix to the parametrial tissues but not to the pelvic wall. In this case, the involvement of the lateral pelvic wall suggests a more advanced stage.

OPTION B: Stage IIIA: It refers to the spread of the cancer to the lower third of the vagina but without extension to the pelvic wall. This is not consistent with the findings of a mass extending to the pelvic wall.

OPTION D: Stage IVA: It involves the spread of the tumor to adjacent organs such as the bladder or rectum but not the pelvic wall. The involvement of the pelvic wall is more consistent with Stage IIIB.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

FIGO staging of Cervical Cancer:-

choices.text: Administer the second dose and complete the series with a third dose
No further doses are required as a lot of time has passed

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has received her first dose of the HPV vaccine but missed the second dose due to COVID-19 pandemic. She returns 12 months later. What is the most appropriate advice you would give her as a health care provider?
questions.solution:
If the interval between the first and second dose is extended, the series should still be completed by administering the missed second dose followed by the third dose according to the recommended schedule. The effectiveness of the vaccine is not compromised by the delay.

OPTION A: Restarting the HPV vaccination series is not necessary, even if the second dose is delayed. The series can be continued without restarting.

OPTION C: Even if a significant amount of time has passed, it is still important to complete the vaccination series to ensure full protection.

OPTION D: A single booster dose is not sufficient. The patient should receive the second and third doses as per the original schedule to complete the vaccination series.

KEY TAKEAWAY: If the second dose of the HPV vaccine was not taken within the recommended 6-month period, the patient should not restart the vaccination series. Instead, the following steps should be taken:

  • Administer the missed second dose as soon as possible.
  • Complete the vaccination series by giving the third dose according to the original schedule (typically 6 months after the second dose).

Reference: CDC Guidelines on HPV Vaccination

choices.text: Immediate surgical resection of the mass
Repeat MRI in 3 months to assess for changes
PET-CT scan to assess metabolic activity of the mass
Paracentesis to determine if the cancer has spread

questions.text: A 58 year-old woman is undergoing follow-up after completing chemoradiation for stage IIIB cervical cancer. A post-treatment MRI shows a residual mass in the pelvis. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
After treatment, distinguishing between residual disease and post-treatment changes can be challenging. A PET-CT scan can help assess the metabolic activity of the mass to determine if it is active disease or scar tissue.

OPTION A: Immediate surgical resection of the mass is not typically the first step in managing a residual mass after chemoradiation in stage IIIB cervical cancer. Surgery in this context is often considered only after confirming the nature of the residual mass.

OPTION B: Repeat MRI in 3 months to assess for changes: While repeating imaging can be useful, waiting for another 3 months may delay necessary treatment if the mass is active disease. More definitive assessment is needed.

OPTION D: Paracentesis to determine if the cancer has spread: Paracentesis is used to sample fluid from the abdomen, typically in cases of ascites, and is not appropriate for assessing a pelvic mass directly. It is not useful in this context for evaluating the residual mass.

KEY TAKEAWAY: In a patient with a residual pelvic mass after chemoradiation for stage IIIB cervical cancer, the best next step is to perform a PET-CT scan to assess the metabolic activity of the mass. This helps in determining whether the mass represents active cancer requiring further treatment or post-treatment changes such as fibrosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with early-stage endometrial cancer is scheduled for total hysterectomy. Preoperative imaging with MRI shows deep myometrial invasion (>50%) and possible cervical stromal involvement. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her cancer?
questions.solution:
Deep myometrial invasion with cervical stromal involvement is consistent with FIGO stage II endometrial cancer. This staging impacts surgical planning, often necessitating more extensive surgery and consideration of adjuvant therapy.

OPTION A: Stage IA endometrial cancer is confined to the endometrium or involves less than half of the myometrium. The deep myometrial invasion (>50%) described in this case excludes Stage IA.

OPTION B: Stage IB endometrial cancer involves more than half of the myometrium but is confined to the uterus without cervical stromal involvement. Since there is possible cervical stromal involvement in this case, it is not Stage IB.

OPTION D: Stage IIIA involves serosal, adnexal, or positive peritoneal cytology, which is not described in this case. The cancer is still confined to the uterus with cervical stromal involvement, making Stage II the most appropriate option.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Reference: NCCN guidelines on Endometrial Cancer

questions.text: A 58-year-old obese woman with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents with postmenopausal bleeding. She is diagnosed with endometrial cancer. Which of the following risk factors is most strongly associated with her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
OPTION A: Obesity (Relative Risk: 3-10x)

Obesity is the most significant risk factor for endometrial cancer. The relative risk increases as the body mass index (BMI) increases. Obesity leads to higher levels of circulating estrogen due to the conversion of androgens to estrogen in adipose tissue, a process known as aromatization. This unopposed estrogen exposure to the endometrium results in increased risk of hyperplasia and subsequent development of endometrial cancer.

OPTION B: Hypertension (Relative Risk: 1.2-1.5x)

Hypertension is a weaker risk factor for endometrial cancer compared to obesity. The association may be partly due to its common coexistence with obesity and metabolic syndrome rather than being an independent risk factor.

OPTION C: Diabetes mellitus (Relative Risk: 2-3x)

Diabetes mellitus is another important risk factor, especially type 2 diabetes, which is often associated with obesity and hyperinsulinemia. Insulin resistance and increased insulin levels can promote endometrial cancer development. However, the relative risk is lower than that associated with obesity.

OPTION D: Smoking (Relative Risk: Decreased Risk)

Interestingly, smoking is associated with a decreased risk of endometrial cancer. This protective effect is thought to be due to anti-estrogenic effects of smoking, which include reduced body weight and lower circulating estrogen levels. However, smoking is a risk factor for many other cancers, particularly lung cancer.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Estrogen levels are directly proportional to risk of Endometrial cancer.

CORPUS CANCER SYNDROME: The triad of obesity, hypertension, and diabetes is known as the corpus cancer syndrome triad, and it's a major factor in the increasing prevalence of endometrial cancer (EC) worldwide.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with Lynch syndrome presents for routine screening and is found to have endometrial cancer. Which histological subtype is she most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Women with Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) are at increased risk for endometrioid adenocarcinoma, the most common histological subtype associated with this genetic condition. Lynch syndrome is linked to mutations in DNA mismatch repair genes, leading to a higher risk of endometrial and colorectal cancers.(colorectal>endometrial).

OPTION A: Serous carcinoma is a more aggressive subtype of endometrial cancer, but it is not the most common subtype associated with Lynch syndrome. It is typically seen in older women without a genetic predisposition.

OPTION B: Clear cell carcinoma is another aggressive subtype, often seen in postmenopausal women. Like serous carcinoma, it is less commonly associated with Lynch syndrome compared to endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

OPTION D: Squamous cell carcinoma is very rare in the endometrium and is not typically associated with Lynch syndrome.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Endometrial Cancer in Lynch Syndrome (HNPCC)

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with BRCA1 mutation presents for a routine follow-up. She is asymptomatic but is concerned about her risk of ovarian cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate preventive strategy?
questions.solution:
For women with a BRCA1 mutation, prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is the most effective strategy to significantly reduce the risk of developing ovarian cancer. This surgery significantly lowers the risk of ovarian cancer by removing the ovaries and fallopian tubes, where the majority of ovarian cancers originate.

OPTION A: Regular CA-125 screening every 6 months: While CA-125 is a tumor marker often elevated in ovarian cancer, it is not specific and can be elevated in benign conditions. Additionally, by the time CA-125 is elevated, ovarian cancer may already be advanced. Therefore, it is not considered a reliable screening tool for early detection in high-risk women.

OPTION B: Pelvic ultrasound annually: Pelvic ultrasound can be used to monitor ovarian morphology, but like CA-125, it has limitations in detecting early-stage ovarian cancer. Screening with ultrasound alone is not sufficient to reduce mortality in women at high risk due to BRCA1 mutation.

OPTION D: Oral contraceptive use: While oral contraceptives have been shown to reduce the risk of ovarian cancer, this option is less effective compared to prophylactic surgery. It may be considered for those who wish to delay surgery but are not as effective as surgical intervention for long-term prevention in BRCA1 carriers.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

The recommendation for prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO) in women with a BRCA1 mutation is based on strong evidence linking this surgery to a significant reduction in ovarian and fallopian tube cancer risk.

The decision is further supported by two theories: the "STIC" theory and the "SCOUT" theory.

STIC Theory (Serous Tubal Intraepithelial Carcinoma)

  • Concept: The STIC theory suggests that many high-grade serous ovarian cancers (HGSC), which are common in BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutation carriers, actually originate in the fallopian tubes, specifically in the distal portion (fimbriae). Serous tubal intraepithelial carcinoma (STIC) lesions in the fallopian tubes are considered precursors to ovarian cancer.

SCOUT Theory (Secretory Outgrowths)

  • Concept: The SCOUT theory postulates that high-grade serous carcinomas can arise from a continuum of changes that begin in the fallopian tubes and spread to the ovaries and peritoneum. This model sees the fallopian tubes as the primary source of malignancy that later involves the ovaries.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with abdominal distension, a palpable pelvic mass, and a right-sided pleural effusion. After surgical evaluation and resection of the ovarian mass, the pleural effusion resolves. Which benign ovarian tumor is most commonly associated with Meigs' Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ovarian fibromas are the benign ovarian tumors most commonly associated with Meigs' Syndrome(ovarian tumor + ascites +right sided pleural effusion).

OPTION A: Dermoid cysts (mature teratomas) are benign ovarian tumors that are composed of different types of tissues. While they can cause abdominal discomfort and other symptoms, they are not typically associated with Meigs' Syndrome.

OPTION B: Serous cystadenomas are benign ovarian cysts that are filled with a clear, serous fluid. Although they can cause symptoms related to their size and pressure, they are not commonly linked with Meigs' Syndrome.

OPTION D: Granulosa cell tumors are a type of sex-cord stromal tumor that can be benign or malignant. They are not commonly associated with Meigs' Syndrome.

KEY TAKEAWAY: The resolution of the pleural effusion after resection of the ovarian mass supports the diagnosis of Meigs' Syndrome.

choices.text: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO) only

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with mucinous adenocarcinoma of the ovary. During staging, it is found that the tumor has metastasized to the peritoneum and appendix. What is the most appropriate surgical approach for this patient?
questions.solution:
For mucinous adenocarcinoma of the ovary with peritoneal and appendiceal involvement, a comprehensive surgical approach is required, including TAH-BSO, omentectomy, and appendectomy. This approach helps in staging, reducing tumor burden, and addressing any synchronous malignancies.

TAH-BSO addresses the primary ovarian tumor and associated reproductive organs. Omentectomy is crucial because the omentum is a common site for metastatic spread in ovarian cancer. Appendectomy is needed since the tumor has metastasized to the appendix, and removing it can help control the spread of the disease and prevent further complications.

OPTION A: Total abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (TAH-BSO) only: While TAH-BSO is a common part of the surgical treatment for ovarian cancer, it is not sufficient when the cancer has metastasized to other sites like the peritoneum and appendix.

OPTION D: Appendectomy alone: This option is inadequate as it only addresses one site of metastasis and does not deal with the primary ovarian tumor or other metastases.

KEY TAKEAWAY: For patients with ovarian cancer that has spread beyond the ovaries, a comprehensive surgical approach including TAH-BSO, omentectomy is essential to manage the disease effectively. Ovarian mucinous tumors, particularly mucinous adenocarcinomas, can metastasize to the appendix. Removing the appendix during surgery allows for the assessment and removal of any metastatic disease that might be present.

questions.text: Hobnail cells are a characteristic finding in which type of ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
Hobnail cells are characteristic of clear cell carcinoma of the ovary. These cells have a distinct appearance with nuclei protruding into the lumen of the cysts or glands, giving them a “hobnail” appearance.

OPTION A: Serous cystadenocarcinomas are malignant tumors that are typically composed of cells resembling the fallopian tube epithelium. These tumors do not characteristically exhibit hobnail cells; instead, they may show papillary structures with psammoma bodies.

OPTION B: Mucinous cystadenocarcinomas are malignant tumors that produce mucin. These tumors are lined by columnar cells with abundant intracellular mucin, but they do not typically have hobnail cells. The cells are more likely to resemble gastrointestinal epithelium.

OPTION C: Endometrioid carcinoma of the ovary is a malignant tumor that resembles endometrial adenocarcinoma. While it can have complex glandular formations, it does not characteristically display hobnail cells.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

HISTOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF OVARIAN TUMORS

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and heavy menstrual bleeding. Imaging reveals a large ovarian mass. Histological examination shows small round follicles and Call-Exner bodies (as shown in the image). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Granulosa cell tumors are sex cord-stromal tumors of the ovary that are often hormonally active, leading to symptoms such as heavy menstrual bleeding.

OPTION A: Serous cystadenomas are benign ovarian tumors lined by epithelium resembling the fallopian tube. These tumors are typically filled with a thin, watery fluid and do not contain Call-Exner bodies or small round follicles, which are characteristic of granulosa cell tumors.

OPTION B: Mucinous cystadenomas are also benign ovarian tumors but are lined by mucus-producing epithelium. These tumors are generally multilocular and filled with a thick, mucinous fluid. Like serous cystadenomas, they do not exhibit Call-Exner bodies or small round follicles.

OPTION D: Clear cell carcinoma is a malignant epithelial ovarian tumor known for its aggressive behaviour. It is characterized by the presence of clear cells and hobnail cells. However, it does not typically show Call-Exner bodies or small round follicles, which are specific to granulosa cell tumors.

KEY TAKEAWAY: The presence of these Call Exner bodies, along with small round follicles, is strongly indicative of a granulosa cell tumor.

HISTOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF OVARIAN TUMORS

questions.text: Which of the following tumor markers is used in the diagnosis and monitoring of dysgerminoma?
questions.solution:
Dysgerminomas are often associated with elevated levels of LDH, which can be used for both diagnosis and monitoring of the disease. LDH levels correlate with tumor burden and can be an indicator of response to treatment.

OPTION A: CA-125 is a tumor marker primarily used in the diagnosis and monitoring of epithelial ovarian cancers, particularly serous carcinomas.

OPTION B: AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein) is a tumor marker commonly elevated in yolk sac tumors (endodermal sinus tumors) and certain non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

OPTION C: hCG (Human chorionic gonadotropin) is often elevated in choriocarcinomas and other trophoblastic diseases, as well as in some non-seminomatous germ cell tumors. While some dysgerminomas may produce low levels of hCG, it is not the primary marker used for diagnosis or monitoring.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Reference: NCCN Guidelines on Ovarian Cancer

questions.text: A patient with ovarian cancer is found to have tumor confined to both ovaries with both surfaces affected and capsule involvement. What FIGO stage does this suggest?
questions.solution:
Stage I ovarian cancer involves the tumor being confined to one or both ovaries, which may include surface involvement/capsular rupture but no spread beyond the ovaries.

OPTION B: Stage II

  • Stage II ovarian cancer involves spread to pelvic organs outside the ovaries, such as the uterus, fallopian tubes. Since the tumor is still confined to the ovaries in this case, it does not meet the criteria for Stage II.

OPTION C: Stage III

  • Stage III indicates that the cancer has spread beyond the pelvis to the peritoneum or lymph nodes. Since the tumor is confined to the ovaries with surface involvement and capsule rupture but no spread beyond the ovaries, this stage is not applicable.

OPTION D: Stage IV:

  • Stage IV ovarian cancer is characterized by distant metastasis, such as to the liver, lungs, or other organs outside the abdominal cavity. This stage would be considered advanced, and since the tumor is confined to the ovaries, this option is incorrect.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

FIGO STAGING OF OVARIAN CANCER

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with postmenopausal bleeding and a visible mass on the vaginal wall. A biopsy confirms vaginal cancer. Which of the following is the most common type of vaginal cancer?
questions.solution:
Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of vaginal cancer, accounting for about 80-85% of cases. It typically arises from the squamous epithelium lining the vagina and is often linked to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

OPTION B: Adenocarcinoma is less common in the vagina, accounting for about 5-10% of vaginal cancers. It arises from the glandular cells and is more commonly seen in younger women, particularly those exposed to diethylstilbestrol (DES) in utero.

OPTION C: Melanoma of the vagina is rare, comprising less than 3% of vaginal cancers. It originates from melanocytes and is more likely to be found in the lower third of the vagina.

OPTION D: Sarcoma is also rare and include types such as leiomyosarcoma and rhabdomyosarcoma. These tumors arise from the mesenchymal tissue and are more commonly seen in younger patients.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

VAGINAL CANCER

choices.text: Additional surgery to remove remaining lymph nodes

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is diagnosed with vulvar cancer and undergoes surgery. Post-surgical evaluation reveals lymph node metastasis. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Adjuvant radiation therapy is often used after surgery in the presence of lymph node metastasis to address any residual disease. It helps to reduce the risk of recurrence and improve survival outcomes.

OPTION A: Chemotherapy may be used in advanced cases or in combination with radiation therapy, but it is not the first-line treatment for lymph node metastasis in vulvar cancer following surgery.

OPTION B: If the initial surgery did not achieve complete lymph node removal, additional surgery might be considered. However, adjuvant radiation therapy is generally preferred in cases with confirmed lymph node metastasis.

OPTION C: Observation without further treatment would not be appropriate in the presence of lymph node metastasis, as it increases the risk of recurrence and reduces survival chances.

KEY TAKEAWAY: Adjuvant Radiation Therapy is the primary treatment after surgery for Vulvar Cancer if lymph node metastasis is found. It helps reduce the risk of cancer recurrence and improves survival outcomes.

FIGO Staging of Vulval Cancer:-

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with vaginal bleeding and a palpable mass in the vaginal area. Histological examination reveals embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. Which imaging modality is typically used for evaluation of vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma in children?
questions.solution:
OPTION A: MRI is the preferred imaging modality for initial evaluation of vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma in children. It provides detailed images of soft tissue structures, which is essential for assessing the extent of the tumor, its relation to adjacent structures, and planning further treatment.

OPTION B: While CT scans are useful in evaluating the extent of disease and detecting metastasis, they are less effective than MRI for detailed assessment of soft tissue tumors like rhabdomyosarcoma in the vaginal area.

OPTION C: Ultrasound can be used as an initial diagnostic tool to detect the presence of a mass, but it lacks the detail and precision needed to evaluate the full extent of rhabdomyosarcoma and its relationship with surrounding tissues.

OPTION D: X-rays are not typically used for the initial evaluation of vaginal rhabdomyosarcoma as they do not provide sufficient detail for assessing soft tissue tumors or their extent.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Facts about Vaginal Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with irregular vaginal bleeding 8 weeks after a miscarriage. She reports passing grape-like vesicles per vagina. Her β-hCG levels are significantly elevated, and a pelvic ultrasound shows a snowstorm pattern without a viable fetus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of irregular bleeding, passage of grape-like vesicles, markedly elevated β-hCG, and the ultrasound finding of a snowstorm pattern are classic for a complete molar pregnancy. This condition is characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation without any fetal tissue.

OPTION A: Ectopic pregnancy typically presents with abdominal pain, and the ultrasound may show an empty uterus or an adnexal mass. The characteristic findings of elevated β-hCG and a snowstorm pattern on ultrasound are not consistent with ectopic pregnancy.

OPTION C: While partial molar pregnancy can present with elevated β-hCG and abnormal ultrasound findings, it typically shows some evidence of a fetus or fetal tissue alongside the trophoblastic disease. The absence of a fetus and the snowstorm appearance on ultrasound makes complete molar pregnancy more likely.

OPTION D: Choriocarcinoma is a malignant form of GTD that can develop after any type of pregnancy, including molar pregnancy. It presents with persistently elevated β-hCG, but the typical ultrasound findings differ from those of a molar pregnancy, and it often occurs after the resolution of a molar pregnancy, not as the initial diagnosis.

KEY TAKEAWAY: The correct diagnosis for the patient described in the case is complete molar pregnancy, based on the combination of clinical symptoms, elevated β-hCG levels, and characteristic ultrasound findings.

SOME OF DIFFERENTIAL DIAGNOSIS OF BLEEDING IN FIRST TRIMESTER.

  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Abortion
  • Molar pregnancy
  • Subchorionic hemorrhage

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a history of a complete molar pregnancy underwent suction curettage 4 months ago. Her β-hCG levels have plateaued over the past 3 weeks despite treatment. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Persistent GTD with plateauing β-hCG levels is an indication for chemotherapy.


OPTION A: If the β-hCG levels plateau, this suggests persistent GTD, which is better managed with chemotherapy rather than repeating the procedure.

OPTION C: Hysterectomy is considered in specific cases but is not the first line of management for plateauing β-hCG.

OPTION D: Persistent β-hCG levels despite initial treatment requires active management rather than observation alone.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is being monitored after treatment for a complete mole. Three months after treatment, her beta-hCG levels start to rise again. Further imaging shows metastasis to the lungs. What is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
Multi-agent chemotherapy is the standard treatment for high-risk GTN, especially when there is evidence of metastasis. This approach is necessary to control and eradicate the disease, as it is responsive to chemotherapy. The common regimen includes drugs like EMA-CO (etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine).

OPTION A: Observation and follow-up are not appropriate in this scenario because the rising beta-hCG levels and lung metastasis indicate the presence of high-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN), which requires active treatment. Delaying treatment could lead to disease progression.

OPTION C: Surgical resection is not the first-line treatment for metastatic GTN. Chemotherapy is preferred because it treats both the primary tumor and any metastatic lesions. Surgery might be considered in very selective cases where chemotherapy fails or if there are isolated metastases that are resistant to chemotherapy.

OPTION D: Radiation therapy is not typically used for GTN, as these tumors are more effectively treated with chemotherapy. Radiation might be considered in specific cases of resistant or recurrent disease, but it is not a standard first-line treatment for lung metastasis in GTN.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

  • Low risk GTN

WHO score [0-6] -Methotrexate used

  • HIGH RISK GTN0

WHO score [>/= 7]- Multidrug chemotherapy used(EMACO)

questions.text: Which of the following factors increases the risk of developing post-molar gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN)?
questions.solution:
Very high pre-evacuation beta-hCG levels are strongly associated with an increased risk of developing post-molar GTN. Elevated hCG levels indicate a higher burden of trophoblastic tissue, which is linked to persistent disease.

OPTION A: Maternal age below 20 years is not significantly associated with an increased risk of post-molar GTN. The extremes of maternal age (particularly age >40 years) are more commonly associated with molar pregnancies and an increased risk of GTN.

OPTION B: Twin pregnancy, specifically a co-existing normal twin and a molar pregnancy, does not independently increase the risk of post-molar GTN. The management and risk depend on the molar component rather than the twin pregnancy itself.

OPTION D: A prior history of pre-eclampsia is not directly linked to an increased risk of post-molar GTN. Pre-eclampsia is more commonly associated with molar pregnancies, but it does not independently increase the risk of developing GTN after the molar pregnancy.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

choices.text: PSTT typically presents with low serum beta-hCG levels compared to other forms of GTD
PSTT often occurs years after a normal pregnancy or molar pregnancy
PSTT is highly sensitive to chemotherapy and responds well to it
PSTT is characterized by intermediate trophoblastic cells infiltrating the myometrium

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Placental Site Trophoblastic Tumor (PSTT) except:
questions.solution:
PSTT is known to be less sensitive to chemotherapy compared to other forms of GTD, often requiring surgical management.

OPTION A: PSTT typically presents with low levels of beta-hCG because it produces lower amounts of this hormone compared to other forms of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD).

OPTION B: PSTT can occur years after a normal pregnancy, miscarriage, or molar pregnancy.

OPTION D: PSTT is characterized by the infiltration of intermediate trophoblastic cells into the myometrium

KEY TAKEAWAY:

Mnemonic: "PSTT"

  • P: Persistent low beta-hCG levels
    • PSTT usually has low and persistently elevated beta-hCG levels.
  • S: Slow-growing and late presentation
    • PSTT often presents years after the antecedent pregnancy and tends to grow slowly.
  • T: Trophoblastic cells invade myometrium
    • The tumor is characterized by intermediate trophoblastic cells invading the myometrium.
  • T: Treatment is primarily surgical
    • PSTT is less responsive to chemotherapy, and hysterectomy is often required as the primary treatment.

choices.text: Interval from index pregnancy to start of treatment

questions.text: Which of the following factors is NOT included in the WHO scoring system for assessing the risk of Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN)?
questions.solution:
Uterine size is not a factor in the WHO scoring system for GTN.

OPTION A: Age is a factor in the WHO scoring system, with higher scores for patients older than 40 years.

OPTION B: The type of pregnancy that preceded GTN (e.g., molar pregnancy, abortion, term pregnancy) is a key factor in the scoring system.

OPTION C: The time interval from the end of the antecedent pregnancy to the start of treatment is considered in the scoring system.

Other factors such as pre-treatment hCG level, number of metastases, and prior chemotherapy are considered instead.

KEY TAKEAWAY:

WHO SCORING FOR GTN

Total score: if </=6-low risk : single agent methotrexate given in multidose form.

If >/=7-high risk: EMACO regimen.
